description.narrative: Humanitarian Coordination [AUS] and support services to Papua New Guinea by provision of support and advise to the Government of Papua New Guinea and UN Agencies including other actors for better preparedness and response coordination.

activity-description.narrative: Provision of Humanitarian Coordination and support services to Papua New Guinea.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: Readiness of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced 1). Number of Disaster Management Team actions items supported. 2). Number of disasters monitored and reported. 3). Clusters’ preparedness to respond is improved. 4). Provincial preparedness to respond is improved.
Output 2: Updating the National Disaster Management 1). The number of consultations with key stakeholders conducted.
5). Civil-military coordination is improved. 6). Gender is mainstreamed

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Readiness of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced 1). Disaster Management Team annual terms of reference, work plan and were renewed and accountability compact were adopted in Jan 2020; action items were monitored and resolved 2). 50 situation updates 3). 1 humanitarian response plan for COVID-19 4). 1 updated contingency plan for a La Niña event 5). 4 Disaster Management Team contingency plans (sudden onset, slow onset, civil unrest, refugee emergency) were created in 2019; sudden-onset and slow-onset were updated in 2020. 6). 5 Provincial Disaster Coordinators received needs assessment training in 2019, but no provincial trainings were carried out. 7). No formal engagement of civil-military coordination with the Disaster Management Team. 8). Disaster Management Team members adopted annual terms of reference and member compact that includes specific accountability to uphold the centrality of protection, address gender-based violence, and advocate for protection from sexual exploitation and abuse. 9). Protection Cluster strengthened by a dedicated cluster coordinator, regular meetings of cluster/sub-clusters, active participation in response and contingency planning. 10). Attention elevated on protection concerns under COVID-19 measures. 11), Protection was a focus of revised multi-sectoral response plan for COVID-19
Output 2: Updating the National Disaster Management 1, The Disaster Management Act has not been substantively updated since it was enacted in 1984.

Output 1: Readiness of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced 1). Disaster Management Team annual terms of reference, work plan and compact on accountability are renewed and action are monitored 2). Monitor humanitarian situation and coordinate international humanitarian response, needs assessment, and humanitarian financing 3). Disaster Management Team contingency plans and 4W are current, reflecting preparedness to respond to emergencies 4). At least one PDC’s preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved 5). Papua New Guinea participates in Regional Consultative Group for Civil-Military Coordination 6). Gender mainstreaming is improved across project outputs
Output 2: Updating the National Disaster Management 1). Technical inputs to Disaster Management Act have been incorporated.

Output 1: Readiness of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced
1. Disaster Management Team (DMT) • The DMT renewed its annual terms of reference and accountability compact, approved an annual work plan, and monitored and resolved 3 action items. • The DMT convened 10 regular meetings, 2 ad hoc meetings, and 1 donor meeting. The DMT Secretariat also met with NGO Development Council and regularly briefed United Nations Country Team and Security Management Team. • The project monitored and reported on 31 emergencies in addition to fortnightly updates on COVID19 and regular monitoring of African Swine Fever, Fall Army Worm, and movement of asylum seekers from West Papua.
2. Humanitarian monitoring, response coordination • The project tracked and regularly updated dashboard on international contributions to the COVID-19 response and vaccination rollout. • Coordinated needs assessments and humanitarian financing for king tide flooding across the country. • The project updated the COVID-19 4Ws (Who is doing What, Where, and for Whom) on a quarterly basis and facilitated the regular updating of the Pacific Logistic Cluster’s Pacific Logistics Mapping (PALM) platform.
3. DMT and clusters’ preparedness • As part of its preparedness work, the project led technical assistance on cluster management, the PALM platform, and the development of a Humanitarian Communications Plan for the UN Communications Group. • With Save the Children in PNG, the project initiated work on a national humanitarian cash and voucher assistance working group and with the CDAC Network on a national community engagement working group. These activities are also part of its activities to increase capacities for preparedness and response. • The project reviewed and updated DMT contingency plans for sudden- and slow-onset responses in preparedness for 2020-21 and 2021-22 La Niña events.
4. At least one PDC’s preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved • Activity postponed primarily due to COVID-19-related travel and gathering restrictions and secondarily due to staff incapacity
5. Civil-military coordination • Engagement was maintained but limited due to several factors, including COVID-19 related restrictions, personnel turnover at OCHA ROAP, and diminished participation by PNG NDC/RPNGC/PNGDF representatives
6. Mainstreaming gender • The project tracked participation in HAT project and DMT activities. • The project advocated for protection and inclusion in NCC response activities. • The project ensured protection and inclusion are objectives for preparedness planning.
Output 2: Updating the National Disaster Management
1). The project was able to accomplish one combined regional consultation for the MOMASE and Highlands regions. It was limited by COVID-19-related restrictions for travel and gatherings from conducting

Output 1: Readiness of the Disaster Management Team members and the National Disaster Centre to prepare and respond to disasters enhanced
1). Regular meetings of the Disaster Management Team • Disaster Management Team annual terms of reference, work plan and compact on accountability are renewed and action items are monitored.
2). Semi-annual joint meeting of the Disaster Management Team and National Disaster Committee • National partners’ preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved
3). Quarterly planning meetings of the Inter-Cluster Coordination Group • Disaster Management Team contingency plans and 4W are current, reflecting preparedness to respond to emergencies
4) Preparation for national community engagement working group • National partners’ preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved
5) Preparation for national cash working group • National partners’ preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved
6) Support monitoring of humanitarian situation and coordination of international humanitarian response in the country, including needs assessment and humanitarian financing • Disaster Management Team contingency plans and 4W are current, reflecting preparedness to respond to emergencies
7) Review and revision of the contingency plans • Disaster Management Team contingency plans and 4W are current, reflecting preparedness to respond to emergencies
8) Needs assessment training for national partners • National partners’ preparedness to respond to disasters and emergencies is improved
Output 2: Updating the National Disaster Management
1). Provide technical support and consultation to the National Disaster Centre for updating the National Disaster Management Act • Technical inputs to Disaster Management Act have been incorporated.
